contentrichtext.text: '''Lucius Furius Philus''' was a [[consul]] of [[ancient Rome]] in 136 BC. He was a member of the Scipionic circle, and particularly close to [[Scipio Aemilianus]]. As consul he was involved with the ''foedus Mancinum'', and offered Mancinus to the [[Numantia|Numantines]]. He is mentioned by [[Macrobius]] as the author of a work mentioning two sacral formulae to use against besieged cities, while [[Cicero]], in ''[[de Republica]]'', praises the style of Furius' speeches. == References == * [[Cicero]], [[de Republica]] * [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Cassius_Dio/18*.html Cassius Dio, Roman History] * Rawson, Elizabeth (1973) Scipio, Laelius, Furius and the Ancestral Religion, The Journal of Roman Studies, Vol. 63, pp. 161â€“174 {{S-start}} {{Succession box|title=[[List of Roman Republican consuls|Consul]] of the [[Roman Republic]]|before=[[Marcus Aemilius Lepidus Porcina]] and [[Gaius Hostilius Mancinus]]||after=[[Servius Fulvius Flaccus]] and [[Quintus Calpurnius Piso]]|years=''with [[Sextus Atilius Serranus]]''<br /> 136 BC}} {{S-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Philus, Lucius Furius}} [[Category:Roman Republican consuls|Furius Philus, Lucius]] [[Category:Furii]] [[Category:2nd-century BC Romans]] {{AncientRome-politician-stub}}
